WASHINGTON, Aug. 2.--Secretary Adams has forwarded to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, retired, to gold medal awarded to him by Congress in commemoration of his leadership of the Byrd Antarctic Expetition to Little America and the South Pole. Aug. 14--A denouement without precedent, so far as is known, in a championship tournament sanctioned by the United States Lawn Tennis Association, marked the final round of the women's Eastern championship singles at the Westchester Country Club today and precluded, the possibility of a titleholder being established for 1931.

Yesterday marked the end of the Summer sessions for 18,000 children in the elementary grades in New York City. They had either been making up low marks of last year, or studying ahead for higher marks next year.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 14.--Cleveland clinched the honors in its season's athletic relations with the Yankees by winning today's double-header, 13 to 7 and 9 to 1, making three out of four for the series. The Indians have won 12 of their 19 games with the Yankees this year, with three left to play in Yankee Stadium next month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 14.--The price war among the large oil companies brought new price cuts in gasoline today, and if no motorists were seen dancing in the streets it was not because they lacked reason to do so. The latest cuts, effective tomorrow, have put prices at their lowest in Chicago history.

A well-known pastime of Harlem's youth, known as "baiting the bystander," resulted last night in one death and the serious wounding of two other persons. The 16-year-old boy, whose conduct was responsible for the tragedy, was arrested charged with felonious assault.

The fluctuating course of the infantile paralysis outbreak brought another considerable decline yesterday in the daily report of new cases. Fashion developments at the Paris openings curbed Fall buying to some extent in the wholesale apparel markets last week, although the volume of orders reached fair proportions. The Goldman Band closed its fourteenth season of Summer concerts last night with a concert on the Mall in Central Park. About 40,000 persons were present to hear the program conducted by Edwin Franko Goldman, leader of the band, who has not missed a single performance in the fourteen seasons.

Gifford, director of President Hoover's Organization for Unemployment Relief, and representatives of national welfare organizations on preparations for Winter, all agencies planning relief fund drives were urged to unite in a nation-wide appeal between Oct. 19 and Nov. 25.

BUFFALO, N.Y., Aug. 25.--Albert L. Kinsey, 51 years old, president of the Kinsey Realty Company and prominent in the social and business life of Buffalo, walked slowly into one of his subdivisions on the outskirts of the city at 10 o'clock this morning and ended his life with a revolver.

LONDON, Aug. 25.--Foreign confidence in the Bank of England has been restored and the danger to the stability of sterling exchange has been averted by the change in the British Government, with its implied assurance of early budgetary reforms, London banking interests say.

MOSCOW, Aug. 25.--During the past week there have been considerable, if behind the scenes, alarums and excursions about the construction of the huge Soviet steel works, Magnitogorsk. High officials have met in conclave, and Colonel Cooper has come back from his inspection of Magnitogorsk and said his say.

LONDON, Aug. 25.--Philip Snowden, Chancellor of the Exchequer in the new National Government, showed tonight that he was in complete accord with his leader, Prime Minister MacDonald, regarding both the causation and cure of Britain's financial ills.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25.--Almost 11 per cent of the nation's population was foreign-born white when the 1930 census was taken, the Census Bureau announced today. There were 13,366,407 foreign-born white, or 10.9 per cent of the entire population.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Aug. 25.-- A field that probably set a record for one-day tournaments turned out for the Metropolitan Golf Association eighteen-hole handicap event at the Winged Foot Golf Club today, but for the vast majority of the 278 entrants it was just a day in the country.

The average daily gross crude oil production in the United States for the week ended Aug. 22 was 2,608,250 barrels, compared with 2,498,500 in the preceding week, an increase of 109,750, according to the American Petroleum Institute. The production east of California averaged 2,092,950 barrels daily, against 1,981,500 in the preceding week, a gain of 11,450.

SHANGHAI, Wednesday, Aug. 26 (AP).--The flooded Wuhan area, comprising the Central China cities of Hankow, Wuchang and Hanyang, survived yesterday's typhoon, one of the worst since 1905, without great additional damage, it was learned today, but high winds swept turbulent waters through Hankow, causing many walls tot collapse.

The certificate of incorporation of the Kings-Queens Milk Dealers Association, whose membership will comprise more than 80 per cent of the wholesale milk dealers of the two counties, according to Maurice Biederman, executive secretary of the association, was signed yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Dodd in Brooklyn.

FARMINGTON, Conn., Aug. 25.-- Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Cowles, sister of the late President Theodore Roosevelt and widow of Rear Admiral William Sheffield Cowles, died at Oldgate, her home here, tonight at 8:30 o'clock. She was 76 years old. Her health had been poor for several years.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Aug. 25.-- In a preliminary race to the Atlantic Coast Star Class championship, Paul Shields's Shinnecock, sailed by his brother Corny Shields, today led twelve other Star boats on Long Island Sound. Shinnecock came in 2 minutes and 23 seconds ahead of L.W. Reybine's Lout, which was three minutes before Howard McMichael's Grey Fox.

PARIS, Aug. 25.--In France, where financial stability was obtained only by the sacrifice of four-fifths of the value of the pre-war franc and the consequent reduction of the internal debt to one-fifth of its subscribed value, England's struggle to save the pound is being watched with passionate interest.

Hazleton Jr., who has been missing since last Thursday.

Music has its charms even in a butcher shop. To relieve the commonplace appeal of pot roasts and sausages Leon Weiser placed a sixpiece band in front of his meat emporium at 54 Amsterdam Avenue. He found that it helped business.

BERLIN, Aug. 25.--The mystery plane on the island of Novaya Zemlya, spotted on a film taken during the Graf Zeppelin's recent Arctic cruise, is getting more and more mysterious with each new explanatory theory advanced.

William J. Moore, former president of the American Bond and Mortgage Company, which is said to have sold $240,000,000 in bonds since its organization as a corporation in Maine during 1904, was indicted yesterday on sixteen counts alleging mail fraud and on a seventeenth count charging conspiracy.

STAMFORD, Conn., Aug. 25.-- Edwin Linwood Witham, advertising manager of The Stamford Advocate for eight years, died last evening at his home,16 Clovelly Road, of a complication of diseases. His age was 58.

UTICA, N.Y., Aug. 25.--Charles Wells Wicks, former State Senator from Oneida County and for a generation a prominent member of business and civic circles of Utica, died early today at his home at Curtis Point, Me., near Kennebunkport, where he had resided for the last three years. He was 68 years old.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 25.--Both industrial production and factory employment declined more than the usual seasonal amounts in July, the Federal Reserve Board stated today in its monthly summary. The general level of commodity prices remained unchanged and conditions in the money market continued easy.

SOUTHAMPTON, L.I., Aug. 25.-- Many members of the Summer colonies of East Hampton, Southampton and Westhampton attended the recital of Willard Fry, American baritone, this afternoon at the studio at Wayside, the home of his uncle, Marshall Fry. LONDON, Aug. 25.--Although business on the Stock Exchange was small again today, steady to firm conditions ruled in most sections, with traders awaiting political developments, especially measures to balance the budget.

Dunnigan, Democratic minority leader of the Senate, demanding that Mr. Macy back investigations of up-State villages and counties. Mr. Macy declared that he was "in favor of the investigation and elimination of corruption at all times, and under all circumstances, without regard to party."

Albert Coates, the versatile director of the final three weeks of the Stadium Summer concerts, conducted his own "Suite from Music" to Shakespeare's "Taming of the Shrew" last night. Cavanaugh, who will start his fifth year as the Maroon coach. After Wednesday there will be two practice sessions daily until Sept. 14, when classes will begin. Then the drills will be limited to one daily.

PARIS. VARIETY is the chic slogan of the Paris couturiers' Winter campaign. Whether they go in for the picturesque, late Victorian racket, or whether they sponsor uncompromising modernism, they are all death on uniformity.

Almost 600 corporations will distribute dividends on Tuesday, Sept. 1 and about 800 in all will mail checks to their stockholders in the course of the month. The total amount to be disbursed is estimated at $350,000,000, comparing with around $475,000,000 paid in dividends in September, 1930, by more than 900 companies.

More than 18,000 persons visited the Glenn H. Curtiss airport at North Beach, Queens, between 8 A. M. and dusk yesterday to view the huge German flying boat, Do-X, which is moored 200 yards from the edge of the broad apron in front of the Police Department hangar.

ALL this week and through Labor Day air-minded America will have an opportunity to see what the airplane of today can do at the National Air Races at the Cleveland Municipal Airport.

CURACAO, Aug. 24.--General Vincenzio Perez Soto, President of the State of Zulia, has returned to Maracaibo after a stay of several weeks in Caracas with President Gomez, and according to authentic information obtained here, has deferred for the present his ambition to become Vice President of Venezuela.

Expansion of population and the demand for suburban homes have fostered activity oP home builders in many parts of Queens, points out the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce, which estimates that the present population of the borough is above 1,100,000, as compared with 469,000 in 1920 and 1,079,329 as shown by last year's census.

The lower east side, long urged as a proper location for model apartment projects, due to the dilapidated condition of many of the old buildings and the comparatively low prices at which some of the and may be purchased, has a new housing project for wage earners under way in the west blockfront of Avenue A, between East Fifteenth and East Sixteenth Streets.
IT may be helpful to returning vacationists, and to motorists in general, to indicate the condition of New York State highways with respect to construction work and its probable effect on travel.

JOINING the forces seeking to educate automobile drivers in the fundamentals of motor car operation, the Travelers Insur ance Company of Hartford, Conn., has begun to issue a series of messages to motorists.
ASHUBERT booking sheet, which may or may not be writ to sand, brings news as to where a few of the shows now in preparation will hold forth.

BRUSSELS, Aug. 18.--There is a terrible to-do along the Belgian coast, this Summer, owing to the varying standards of decency of the local burgomasters and heads of the police, who are absolute monarchs as far as the behavior of the visitors is concerned.

THIS new volume about Porto Rico provides what is prob ably the most comprehensive single volume survey of the checkered history of this Caribbean island from the obscure pre-Indian days to the current time.
THE 1931 motor-boat racing season, which has attractel large crowds of pleasure-boat owners as spectators, will virtually come to a close in September.
Construction details of the new $700,000 gymnasium at Rutgers University, New Brunswick, N.J., were revealed here yesterday by York Sawyer, architects.

LAKE PLACID.--Throughout the Adirondacks and the Champlain Valley, this week will largely be devoted to preparing for the next, when colorful September, regarded by many as the most beautiful month in the Adirondacks and Champlain Valley, will be greeted with numerous notable social events.

AFTER, a year or two of civic distress New York has been afflicted with an attack of gang violence of a particularly serious and sensational character. Not that robberies and gangster killings are new; every year takes a generous toll.
A FIFTEEN-YEAR-OLD violinist, Felix Slatkin, is listed as the soloist during an orchestral concert in St. Louis today at 11:30 A.M., Eastern Daylight Time. WABC is the New York outlet.

SILVER BAY, Aug. 29.--American workers will not always remain patient sad docile in the face of economic distress and suffering, and revolution in the United States may follow unless order and planning are introduced to avert situations like the present depression, Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, told the industrial conference here, which adjourned tonight.

PROFESSIONAL entertainers have been thriving during the depression, judging from the report of the National Broadcasting Company's Artist Service, a booking agency, which reveals that returns from engagements secured for its artists have totaled $10,000,000 during the past twelve months.

The credit position of Greece, according to a survey just completed by the Institute of International Finance, which organization is conducted by the Investment Bankers' Association in cooperation with New York University, hinges on the fact that the service on the government's debt will absorb about 38 per cent of the estimated revenues for the fiscal year 1931-1932.

A no-hit, no-run game twirled by Frank Lagambino, 16-year-old ace of the Staten Island Red Top Flashes, featured his team's 11-0 victory over the Macks, Manhattan champions, and enabled the winners to gain the final in the Kiwanis League interborough championship series at the Yanke stadium yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 29.--The readiness with which France granted the $200,000,000 share of the $400,000,000 credit to Great Britain is widely characterized today as a gesture of international solidarity destined to accomplish much in restoring Anglo-French relations to their former basis of intimacy.

PATERSON, N.J., Aug. 29.--William T. Davis Jr., 23-year-old son of a prominent painting contractor here, shot and instantly killed his wife, from whom he was separated.

MAHATMA GANDHI'S limited luggage for his voyage to England is likely to contain a copy of Thoreau's essay on "Civil Disobedience," according to dispatches from India.

COOPERSTOWN, N.Y., Aug. 29.-- Foster Ware, editor and writer, formerly of the staffs of The New York Evening Post and THE NEW YORK TIMES, died at Bassett Memorial Hospital here today after a lingering illness. He was in his forty-fifth year.

ACCORDING to the plane of the International Illumination Con gress, London will be bathed in a rainbow of light in connection with the sessions of the congress to be held in that city next month.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29.--Gallant oId Sun Beau, plutocrat of the turf, rolled up a new high mark as champion money-winning thoroughbred of the world today, when he galloped to victory in winning the $25,000 added Lincoln Handicap before a cheering crowd of 20,000.

Prices in the New York commodity markets generally declined last week, with positions in rubber and hides touching new record levels. Trading volume was better generally than for some time, due chiefly to liquidation of September contacts. Lack of supporting developments, rather than decreases caused by bearish sentiment, permitted price levels to drift lower.

SEVERAL steatite effigies of deepsea sharks, porpoises and whales were found recently by Arthur R. Sanger, a Los Angeles archaeologist, on the northern shore of San Clemente Island, fifty miles off the coast of Southern California.

With the peak of the Fall moving season only a month away, leasing of apartment space is providing one of the features of the realty market. During the past week brokers reported the closing of a large number of residential leases, and forecast an increasing amount of activity in this field during the first weeks in September.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29.--Saratoga's mud, famous for its contribution to upsets, figured in another when John J. Robinson's Lucky Tom, at 20 to 1, gained an easy victory in the Grand Union Hotel Stakes, which had its twentyeighth renewal over a heavy track today.

DETROIT, Aug. 27.--With an announced maximum allotment of $7,000,000 for public welfare relief in 1932 and an estimated minimum requirement of $13,500,000 for this purpose, Detroit's interest in the possibility of national aid has become intense.

"Better brains have been applied to the production of automobiles than to the production of residences," said Professor H.E. Hoagland of Ohio State University speaking at the centennial convention of the United States Building and Loan League held at Philadelphia, Pa., last week.

CHICAGO, Aug. 29 (AP).--High winds and high hopes today marked the preparations of America's foremost amateur golfers, together with a sprinkling of British rivals, for the national amateur championship, which starts Monday over the long and difficult layout of the Beverly Country Club.

Bonds of various municipalities constituted the only additions last week to the list of issues called for redemption in August before their maturity dates. GEORGE BERNARD SHAW'S article on Russia and America, published in our Special Features Section today, will be generally taken, it is to be supposed, as a supreme example of his flippant hilarity. Influenced by an improvement in the stock market and the heaviest rainfall of the week in the South. prices on the Cotton Exchange strengthened again yesterday. After a slight decline at the opening, scarcity of contracts advanced prices 15 points to the highest levels of the week and the list closed 6 to 8 points higher than on Friday.

News received here yesterday from Dr. Darwin O. Lyon, American scientist, revealed details of the first of a series of rocket experiments in Tripoli, Africa, to test certain forms of explosive, the possibility of steering by "fins" or "vanes," and the best method of launching. Dr. Lyon is working under the auspices of the Royal Meteorological Observatory of Libya.

Expenditure for State live-stock ranches in Soviet Russia this year will total $453,000,000, in addition to the $200,000,000 to be expended by the end of 1932 in the construction of thirty-nine packing plants, according to an article to appear in the September issue of The Economic Review of Soviet Russia, published by the Amtorg Trading Corporation.

Excessive supplies of fruits and vegetables, especially peaches and tomatoes, demoralized local market trading toward the end of the week, according to the weekly survey of Dr. Arthur E Albrecht, director of the New York office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, issued yesterday.

The great majority of the American delegation to the recent World zionist Congress at Basle applied itself to averting continued internal dissension in the organization and accomplished that object, Robert Szold, chairman, said yesterday in a statement on behalf of the administration of the Zionist Organization of America.

CLEVELAND, Aug. 29.--With parade and pageant in the air and on the ground, the national air races for 1931 got under way here today. There was no racing, but there was much else to entertain the 8,000 persons scattered through the stands built to accommodate 50,000.

PORTLAND, Ore., Aug. 27.--In the reaction following the recent announcement of Senator Charles L. McNary that he favored a resubmission of the entire prohibition question to the people, it has become evident that Oregon is beginning to look askance at the Eighteenth Amendment and corollary laws to an extent that may develop into a reversal of State policy.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--A proposal to use vessels owned by the Shipping Board which are now rotting at their wharves to transport wheat that it is expected will be sold to China by the Farm Board is being studied by the two government organizations, it was reported in an authoritative quarter today. If this were done, the vessels would be sold in the Orient or abandoned there.

Retail trade was subject to unequal conditions in various sections of the country last week, unseasonable weather in northern areas offsetting to some extent the development of activity in special sales of Summer goods, while in warmer sections the movement of goods through strenuous advertising efforts at lower prices was satisfactory.

Gifford, director of the new Federal relief organization, to take charge of all welfare activities of the latter, according to reports current in Washington today.

NEWPORT, R.I., Aug. 29.--Miss Hope Bennett, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas Linwood Bennett of New York and this city, was married this afternoon in Trinity Church to Walter F. Wyeth Jr., son of Walter F. Wyeth of Waban, Mass.

Last week's developments in the British financial crisis, culminating in the opening of a one-year $400,000,000 credit for the support of sterling exchange by private bankers in Paris and New York, constituted, in the view of bankers here, the most important event witnessed in the entire two years of the depression.

PITTSBURGH, Aug. 27.--A proposal of leading interest in the discussion of means to rescue the distressed bituminous coal industry has been made here by J.T.M. Stoneroad, president of the Carnegie Coal Company.

Between 1920 and 1930 the centre of population in the United States moved 22.3 miles west and 7.6 miles south from a point 2 miles west of Whitehall, Owen County, Ind., to a point 3 miles northeast of Linton, Greene County. It thus appears that earlier claims by Illinois to have captured the centre of population were premature.

NEWPORT.--Though September is at hand no one in the Summer colony has begun to think about closing the sea son. A large percentage, it appears, is to remain at the Summer villas until well into the Autumn and the prospects are bright for a lively late season of social activities.

GENEVA, Aug. 27.--Of all the countries in Europe today which are in need of long-term loans there is only one, in the view of competent quarters here and in Basle, that has the slightest chance of obtaining one in the United States or elsewhere without first coming to terms with France. That country is Britain.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 29.--A large gain in patronage of the mineral baths here this month has brought out the fact that this famous old spa, for years society's gathering place in August when the champion thoroughbreds of the country match strides, has been rediscovered as a health resort by leaders in the business, professional, financial and social worlds.

ST. CATHARINES, Ont., Aug. 29 (Canadian Press).--Charles G. McGhie, vice president and general manager of the Welland Vale Manufacturing Company, died suddenly of heart disease today.

LONDON, Aug. 28.--David Lloyd George, leader of the Liberal party and the man who would, doubtless, have made one of the greatest contributions one way or the other in the settlement of the recant political crisis, has recovered sufficiently from his severe operation to define his attitude toward the new national government.

GUAYAQUIL, Aug. 23.--The "pest hole of the Pacific" no longer deserves that name, which was not entirely an exaggeration in years past, when yellow fever, malaria and later, bubonic plague were accepted as matters of course, as unavoidable as the rainy season or the occasional, earthquakes.

THE contests for places in the In ternational American Opera Com pany in Paris are being continued at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees, Paris, before an audition committee of musicians of repute, comprising Eva Gauthier, Marguerite d'Alvarez, Leopold Dufy, Jan Hambourg, Leopold Godowsky and Francis Macmillan.

Taxation problems and the discussion of plans for organizing more property-owning groups as a means of furthering economy in governmental expenditures and fostering tax reforms will form one of the chief topics to be considered by the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards at its annual convention Sept. 24-26 at the Sagamore Hotel, Lake George.

Nearly 2,000 members of the American Chemical Society will convene tomorrow at Buffalo for the eightysecond meeting of the society, at which leaders in the profession will present several hundred papers, recounting their researches in a wide range of subjects. The sessions will continue until Saturday.

Okeson, commissioner for the Eastern Association for the Selection of Football Officials, today called a meeting for graduate managers, coaches and officials to be held next Saturday at the Hotel McAlpin, New York City. Questions regarding rules will be handed to the commissioner. There will be afternoon and evening sessions.

Crain, will not recommend Mr. Crain's removal, according to information obtained yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES from usually well-informed persons. Through an extension in the group life insurance plan for employes of the Union Oil Company of California, the volume of insurance in force for them will be increased approximatey $6,000,000 to more than $26,500,000, it was announced yesterday. The amended plan will affect 4,700 employes, and will increase the total protected to nearly 6,000.

PARIS. Aug. 29.--Reports are current in Paris that even if The Hague court should decide that the proposed Austro-German customs union does not contravene any existing treaties the Austrian Government will soon announce that it does not intend to continue the negotiation of the proposed union, and momentarily at least renounces the whole project which set the diplomatic world in a flurry last Spring.

RIVERSIDE, Conn., Aug. 29.-- Smoking around in a lazy westsouthwest alr that was spotty, 108 racing craft engaged today in the Riverside Yacht Club's regatta. It was the sixteenth season championship of the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound.

Wall Street bankers find themselves accused of toppling over the Labor Government in Great Britain and applauded at the same time for their "enlightened selfishness" in supplying half of a $400,000,000 credit to the British treasury to prop the pound sterling.

Twelve of the original fifteen Goodwood Cups, awarded annually from 1864 to 1879 to the most popular junior in Columbia College, are among the numerous historic treasures which have been added to the Columbiana Collection of Columbia University, Curator Milton H. Thomas announced yesterday.

PARIS, Aug. 28.--The supreme Summer racing event at Deauville, the Grand Prix carrying $32,000 for the winner, turned out this year to be quite an American affair. In a contest two Pennsylvania Dutchmen, Ralph Strassberger's Celerina, a 17-to-1 shot, beat Joseph Widener's great favorite. Two other Americans, William Littauer and John J. McKeon, won the two preceding races.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Aug. 29.-- Three well-dressed young men, with whom an hour earlier he had apparently joked, feasted and walked, entered the $30-a-day suite of Michael J. (Mickey) Duffy, notorious Philadelphia and New Jersey gangster, in the Hotel Ambassador here today and shot him dead as he slept. His body with five pullet wounds was found in the hotel shortly before 4 P.M.

BATON ROUGE, La., Aug. 29 (AP). --Governor Huey P. Long's plan to declare a holiday in production of cotton during 1932 became a law today that will be operative if States growing three-fourths of the cotton crop adopt similar measures.
LONDON. LAST week-end brought the first decent weather England had had for weeks. The rain clouds broke and a bright sun moderated the chilly August weather.

A suit to recover a $200,000 collection of paintings, including a score of paintings by noted artists, which belonged to Robert Jackson, former capitalist, who is in bankruptcy in Boston, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Brayton Morton, trustee for Jackson's creditors, against the Central Trust Company of Chicago and others.

Coach Harold J. Parker will have three veteran ends available for varsity duty when the City College football team starts training on Tuesday, Sept. 8, at the Lewisohn Stadium. They are Henry J. (Hank) Berger, Sidney Tatarsky and Ned Schwartz, all of them of first-string ranking last Fall.

KARL FREUND, the camera man responsible for the unusual "shots" in such films as "Me tropolis" and "Variety," has worked out a number of interesting angles in "Personal Maid," coming to the Paramount on Friday.

Columbia launches its annual football campaign Tuesday when fortyfour candidates report to Coach Lou Little at Baker Field. Although E.S.S. Carroll broke 100 straight targets at the Mineola traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club yesterday he did note annex the high scratch cup, shooting for targets only. The winner was Lynn Hunt, who broke 98.

Rabbi Schulman, who is a member of the Council of Jewish Agency for Palestine and opposed to nationalistic aims, returned Thursday night on the Mauretania from a trip of three months abroad.

RENO, Nev., Aug. 29--Everett Dean Martin, author and lecturer, has obtained a divorce here from Persis E. Rowell Martin, whose address is given as Hotel Leonori, Madison Avenue and Sixty-third Street, New York City. They were married in New York on Oct. 23, 1915, and had one child.

Although there was an increase of ten new cases of infantile paralysis in New York City for the week ended yesterday as compared with the previous week, health officials expressed assurance that the outbreak was on a decline and would show sharp decreases in the number of cases reported during the next few weeks.

BUENOS AIRES, July 22. THE appointment of Professor Max Hofmuller, some months ago, as intendente of the Buenos Aires Opera House, and the election of an entirely new administrative force, over which he was granted peremptory control, constituted the first resolute action toward a long-anticipated reorganization of management and improvement of production.
WOODSTOCK, N.Y.--The annual Maverick Festival will be held on Friday afternoon and evening under the management of Hervey White, founder of the Maverick colony in Woodstock.

RED BANK--The American Bridge League has announced plans for a new form of championship event in which individuals will be pitted against each other instead of in pairs or teams to choose the best individual player. Although financial markets ended the week in great dullness, such movement of prices as occurred yesterday was not unfavorable. IN this, her latest story of the South African diamond mines, Sarah Gertrude Millin writes of the same people and the same environment, with a flavor that her readers will remember from her previous novels.

NEW receiving sets, some of which were introduced at the annual radio trade show at Chicago in June, are now finding their way to the market. They will all be on display at the Radio World's Fair at Madison Square Garden the week of Sept. 21.

PORTLAND, Me., Aug. 29.--Alfred Pearce Dennis of Maryland, a Democratic member and former vice chairman of the Tarriff Commission, drowned himself yesterday. His body was found this morning on the shore of Casco Bay near his cottage at Bailey Island.

The recent Mount Shasta fiasco is, from the naval point of view, a good object-lesson against the establishment of a unified air service and a refutation of some of the claims made in the name of aviation by enthusiastic but misguided critics.

ERWIN PISCATOR, the stormy petrel of the German theatre world, is now in Russia direct ing the production of a Soviet talking picture based on the mutiny aboard several German warships at Kiel toward the end of the World War.

The public utility industry has replaced about $560,000,000 of high interest bearing securities with issues carrying lower coupon rates in the first eight months of 1931. This is the greatest refunding operation performed by the industry since 1928, which is the record year for this type of financing.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 29.--The 120th academic year at Princeton Theological Seminary will commence on Tuesday, Sept. 22, one week earlier than usual, it was announced today. According to the revised seminary plan, the academic year will hereafter consist of thirty-four weeks rather than thirty-two as for many years.

CAMP PERRY, Ohio, Aug. 29.-- Twenty-six years ago a middle-aged Spanish-American War veteran "discovered" Camp Perry. With six men as helpers he started to build a rifle range out of a tract of farm and forest land bordering on Lake Erie and put up a few targets to provide shooting practice for the Ohio National Guard.

Polo on the north and south shores of Long Island today will feature teams preparing for the open championship of next month at Meadow Brook, the outstanding event of the season in the game this year.

The essential nature of infantile paralysis has been determined within the twenty-year period during which the disease, escaping from its endemic home in Norway and Sweden, has made its epidemic progress over the world. Only the tropics, and even they not wholly, have been spared its ravages.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--Staging a neck-and-neck race for more than two-thirds of the three-mile swim in the annual Washington Canoe Club President's Cup race today, Ray Ruddy and Ed Lee of the New York A.C. furnished about 2,000 spectators mole thrills than any of the seven previous races provided.

PRINCETON, N.J., Aug. 29.-- Coach Al Wittmer, who replaces Bill Roper as Princeton's new football mentor this Fall, will face many difficulties with his 1931 team. When Coach Wittmer's men arrive here for the first football practice of the season on Sept. 15 he will start work with a squad which lost Fourteen varsity players from last year, including seven of the eleven men who started the Yale-Princeton game.

The Savings Banks Association of the State of New York will hold its thirty-eighth annual convention in Niagara Falls on Sept. 16, 17 and 18. Joseph P. Day expressed the hope yesterday that one of the important topics for serious discussion at this meeting would be the home owners' institution or service which he has been strongly advocating for some time past.

MEXICO CITY, Aug. 29.--The friendly relations between Mexico and China may suffer a setback unless a satisfactory solution is found in the near future for difficulties caused by measures recently adopted in the State of Sonora, where it is now reported that Chinese residents are to have until Sept. 5 to leave Mexican territory or face the risk of being taken across the border.

MOSCOW, Aug. 29.--Life has sharp contrasts in Soviet Russia. Less than a year ago the attention of the country was centred on the Hall of Columns, a former clubhouse for noblemen, where Professor Ramsin and a group of engineers were on trial for their lives. Tonight engineers and the Hall of Columns again form a picture, but how different.

Residential building in Queens and other parts of Long Island is furnishing one of the brightest spots in the metropolitan real estate field during the late Summer season. In a score of communities builders recently have launched new dwelling projects or have carried forward rapidly their construction programs announced earlier in the season.

ANOTHER Cohan, quite in earnest about it, comes to Broadway tomorrow night, promising, in one particular, to make a bow less inauspicious than was her celebrated father's at Keith's Fourteenth Street Variety Theatre in 1893. She refuses to fight with the stagehands.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--Operating schedules in many manufacturing establishments were cut still further and the number of part-time workers increased in July, the monthly employment bulletin of the Federal Employment Service reported today.

The Appellate Division has reversed a decision of the lower court and directed judgment in favor of the Brooklyn Savings Bank in a suit against the estate of Louis Wechsler and others on a contested issue as to a judgment for deficiency in a mortgage foreclosure.

Basing its figures on a three-year lease, the City and Suburban Homes Company yesterday announced the rent schedules that are to prevail at the company's model development in Celtic Park, Queens. The rentals pertain to suites in the first unit of the garden apartment houses occupying the entire blockfront on the south side of Forty-eighth Avenue, from Forty-third to Forty-fourth Street.

PITTSFIELD, Mass.--The Lenox Garden Club Flower Show on Tuesday and Wednesday will open a busy week in the Berkshires. The Pittsfield Country Club Tennis Tournament for the county championships in singles and doubles is to start on Friday and continue over Labor Day.

LONDON. A FRENCH sentimentalist has said that to understand everything is to forgive everything. He was quite wrong. The re sult of a thorough understanding between reciprocally dangerous parties is that they do their best to kill one another.
SERIOUS-MINDED business men this Summer are beset by two major worries: (1) The flight of capital from Germany and (2) the flight of the new golf ball.

DUBLIN, Aug. 27.--All is quiet again on the northern front and it is not expected there will be any repetition of the political or religious skirmishes which recently enlivened country life on the "Lloyd Georgian border," as the Ulster frontier is called by opponents of the treaty with Britain.

STONE HARBOR, N.J., Aug. 29.-- With his motor drumming away in a deafening roar and the throttle wide open, Bill Henderson piloted W.J. McCahan's Floss II to victory in the amateur outboard motor boat freefor-all for the perpetual gold cup that featured the opening of the two-day regatta in the narrow waterway off the Stone Harbor Yacht Club today.

Charles L. Kohler, Director of the Budget, announced yesterday that he had recommended reductions amounting to $1,247,687 in the 1932 budget estimates, submitted by fortyeight city departments, bureaus and agencies, that asked a total of $12,224,095 for the coming year.

FAIEDRICHSHAFEN, Germany. Aug. 29.--The Graf Zeppelin started for South America at 9:36 tonight [4:36 P. M. Eastern Standard Time], cheered by a large crowd which had gathered during the late hours of the afternoon and watched preparations for the non-stop flight. Dr. Eckener and Captain Lehmann took the flight coolly, not showing the slightest nervousness.

A severe dust storm made conditions bad throughout the meet.

BERLIN, Aug. 28.--A Nernst-Siemens-Bechstein piano, a radical innovation but thoroughly tried instrument for universal use, not an experimental curiosity, has been formally placed on the market.

ALBANY, Aug. 29.--Prepared to support the main features of Governor Roosevelt's $20,000,000 emergency unemployment relief program, Republican leaders will give intensive study to the plan over the week-end with the idea of suggesting possible changes in the administration of the relief funds.

DALLAS, Aug. 27.--That peculiar spirit of radicalism abroad in the air today which sent State troops into Oklahoma and East Texas oil fields with the undisguised purpose of forcing up the price of oil, is being felt now in a demand for equally strenuous action to force up the price of cotton.

ALBANY, Aug. 29.--Senator Jonn J. Dunnigan, Democratic leader of the upper house, lashed back at W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, today in a letter dealing with the legislative investigation of New York City and that proposed for up-State cities.

WASHINGTON, Aug. 29.--A further decline of four points during the month ended Aug. 15 in the index number for agricultural prices brought the general level of farm prices to 75 per cent of the pre-war average and the index number to thirty-three points below that of a year ago, the Department of Agriculture announced today.

TORONTO, Ont., Aug. 29.--Production of pig iron in Canada in July amounted to 40,303 long tons, a decline of 28 per cent from the 51,822 tons reported for the preceding month, which in turn was 11 per cent above the 50,511 tons of May. In July, 1930, the output made a total of 64,678 tons.

Mrs. Bohack summoned the family physician, who said her husband had been dead for several hours.

THE track and field events on the charity baseball program to be staged at the Polo Grounds next week are all right as far as they go but they don't go far enough. Ben Chapman, the Yankee sprint champion, is to try for a new record around the bases. Fair enough, but a race with the fastest men of the Giants and Robins running against the Yankee streak would be better yet.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 17.--For the first time since 1926 the trade balance of the United States was unfavorable. Exports totaled $165,000,000, as compared with imports of $166,000,000. This contrasted with a favorable trade balance of $79,348,000 in August, 1930.

The twenty head were auctioned off by Christopher J. Fitzgerald and sold for a total of $36,450, an average of $1,822 per head.

That imports exceeded exports in this country's foreign trade for August need have caused no great surprise; it is not of itself a necessarily disquieting symptom. What it apparently reflects is the drastic reduction of their foreign purchases by European countries, especially those which were subjected to last Summer's financial Strain.

Efforts of Communist organizations to inject themselves into the electric light rate controversy were frustrated yesterday by Milo R. Maltbie, chairman of the Public Service Commission, who refused to hear their spokesman at an adjourned public hearing on the application of the ...

HAVANA, Sept. 18.--Censorship of all telegraph and cable messages was officially lifted today by Secretary of Communications Manuel J. Delgado, who said the government regards all revolutionary activities as terminated and complete peace restored to the nation.

The richest day's racing in America, or for that matter in the world, will be run off this afternoon at Belmont Park, where the six-race program, headed by the $25,000 Futurity, is expected to attract 25,000 spectators.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--A contract covering the sale of the American Diamond Lines to the Black Diamond Steamship Corporation of New York was signed at the Shipping Board today. The Black Diamond Corporation has been managing operator for the service since 1924.

CHICAGO, Sept. 18.--Van Mungo, rangy rookie who joined the Robins eleven days ago, made his third start and won his second game in a tight battle with Charley Root, Cub veteran, today, while 18,000 fans, mostly women taking advantage of ladies' day, looked on with reluctant admiration.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., Sept. 18.-- Billy Burke's quest of a Professional Golfers' Association title to go with the open crown he won at Inverness in July ended today on the thirtysixth green of the Wannamoisset course.

BAYSIDE, L.I., Sept., 18--Adding an 83 to his 80 of yesterday, T. Henry Clarkson of the Old Belleclaire Golf Club today captured the Long Island seniors golf championship with a gross 163 as the annual thirty-sixhole competition was concluded at the Oakland Golf Club course.
NEWARK, Sept. 18.--The Newark Bears defeated the Baltimore Orioles, 9--5, in the first of a three-game series today.

TOKYO, Saturday, Sept. 19.--A violent clash between Chinese and Japanese soldiers in the vicinity of Mukden was followed by all-night fighting which culminated in the capture of the Mukden inner walled city by Japanese troops at 4:30 A.M. today. The fighting is still proceeding in the streets and suburbs.

A cultural federation of the nations of Latin America, which also may lead to a close economic and political union, is urged by Waldo Frank in his study of our Southern neighbors, American Hispana, which Scribner's began publishing yesterday.

Thirty-four new cases of infantile paralysis were reported yesterday by the New York Health Department for the twenty-four-hour period ended yesterday morning. Three deaths were recorded for the city. The number of new cases reported for the day exactly equaled the number of cases reported in the entire first six months of this year.

WESTBURY, L.I., Sept. 18.--Crippled at the last minute by an injury to its No. 1, Alfredo Harrington, who was thrown and injured during the National Polo Pony Show at Meadow Brook today, Argentina's Santa Paula team will make its bid for the United States open championship against the Hurricanes at Meadow Brook tomorrow.

MANILA, Sept. 18.--Secretary of War Patrick J. Hurley, interviewed today at Baguio, revealed that the greatest difficulty of his investigation of independence sentiment in the Philippines has been the unwillingness of many persons to say openly what is readily told confidentially.

LANCASTER, N.H., Sept. 18 (AP) --Judge Eri C. Oakes of the New Hampshire Superior Court committed suicide today a few hours after the consequences of an automobile ride had led to him resign from the bench.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--John F. Nugent, former Senator from Idaho and for seven years a member of the Federal Trade Commission, died of heart disease at 5 o'clock this morning in his home at Silver Spring, Md. He was 63 years old.

Miss Claire Shovlin, 23 years old, of Philadelphia was abducted by four youths in an automobile at 1:30 o'clock yesterday morning within 100 feet of the Pan-Hellenic Hotel, 3 Mitchel Place, one of the fashionable East River sections, where she has lived with her sister, Dorothy, for more than a year.

A petition for control of the Manhattan property of Hisashi Fujimura, Japanese silk importer, who vanished mysteriously from the liner Belgenland on Aug. 14, was filed yesterday in Surrogate's Court by Juichi Kono, vice president of the Asahi Corporation, which the missing man headed.

Awards of fifty-two issues of State and municipal bonds are scheduled for next week. The total is $25,646,100. The amount compares with a revised total of $64,491,322 for the week just ended and a weekly average of $37,825,542 for the vear to date.
MULHALL, Okla., Sept. 18 (AP).-- Colonel Zack Mulhall, pioneer Oklahoma cattleman and one-time wild west showman, died at his ranch home near here early today. His age was 84.

On the Thames below Oxford, across the river from the Wittenham Clumps, rise some ancient Roman earthworks. In days gone by a wealthy nobleman who lived near by tried to relieve unemployment by setting men to work shoveling them away.

Compared to The Chronicle, with its sesquicentennial approaching in 1935, THE NEW YORK TIMES at eighty years is a youthful contemporary. However, its advent into the octogenarian class is an advancement which is unique and glorious in achievement.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--The United States Court of Claims will begin hearings here on Monday of the claim of Robert Esnault-Pelterie, French airplane designer, who asks damages of about $2,500,000 from the government for alleged infringements of his patent of the "single stick" airplane control.

READING, Pa., Sept. 18.--George R. Norris of Dundaly, Md., and Harry R. Todd of Lancaster, Pa., divided the honors in the exciting Central Circuit light harness classes raced today as the feature of the grangers' and farmers' day program at the Greater Reading Fair.

The purchase by Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York of a large plot of land in the West Bronx, near Van Cortlandt Park, was indicated in the filing yesterday of deeds and a mortgage instrument at the Bronx Register's Office.

NEW HAVEN, Sept. 18.--Defending the stand taken by the Rev. Clyde MacIntosh of the Yale Divinity School in declining to subscribe to the principle of bearing arms as an evidence of patriotism and the right of citizenship fifty theologians, editors, educators and authors today memorialized "the President and the Congress of the United States."

Babe Ruth's forty-third homer of the season was the signal for the Yankees to start firing yesterday. The response was so rapid and so hearty that the team rolled ten runs across the plate in the space of two innings, ultimately burying the Browns under a 14-to-4 score. The drive put the Babe one homer behind Gehrig in their duel.
MONTEVIDEO, Sept. 18.--President Terra has approved a bill submitted by the National Administrative Council, designed to end discrimination against the United States in Uruguay's tariff law.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Sept. 18.-- Entry of the United States into the World Court as a step for the promotion of world peace and for restoration of confidence requisite to business recovery was urged today by the convention of the American Bar Association in session here.

HAMPTON, Va., Sept. 18.--Bail of $15,000 was set by Judge C. Vernon Sprately in Circuit Court here today for Professor Elisha Kent Kane of the University of Tennessee, who is being held on a murder charge in connection with the drowning of his wife, Mrs. Jenne Graham Kane, in Chesapeake Bay.

Duties collected under the provisional preferential tariff to go into effect is Brazil in December must be paid entirely in gold, according to the weekly report on foreign tariff changes issued yesterday by the Department of Commerce. At present duties are payable 60 per cent ...

WILMINGTON, Del., Sept. 18.-- Thirteen life or long-term prisoners escaped into the woods from the New Castle County workhouse this morning after a guard and a Negro attempting to escape had been shot.

Heavy selling on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday swept leading stocks and foreign and domestic bonds into new low ground for the year, with public utilities bearing the brunt of the pressure most of the day. Inactive stocks alone showed gains for the day.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Sept. 18.--Two English net stars, Mrs. Elsie Goldsack Pittman and Miss Joan Ridley gained the final round in the sixteenth annual women's invitation tournament of the Ardsley Country Club today. In both instances the winner had to come from behind to triumph after losing the first set.

Details of numerous deals on the west side were made known yesterday through announcements and the recording of contracts at the Register's office. Properties involved were as far uptown as 103d Street and as far south as the Cunard Line piers at the foot of West Fourteenth Street.

PARIS, Sept. 18.--A special committee of experts appointed by the International Chamber of Commerce probably will meet in Paris or London late next week to study the possible value of calling a world silver conference.

Major Bertrand Fay, veteran of the merchant marine and the World War and hero of several rescues from drowning at sea, died on Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital after two weeks of illness from blood poisoning caused by the infection of a slight scratch on his hand.

WHITEMARSH, Pa., Sept. 18.-- Flowing Gold, champion three-gaited saddle horse of America, owned by Mrs. Florence Dibble of Newburyport, Mass., took the blue ribbon in the event open to all three-gaiters at the third day of the Wissahickon Horse Show today.
MOSCOW, Sept. 18.--When is a mutiny not a mutiny?--that is the question puzzling Moscow today as it digests the news--two days late, as usual--of the "movement" in the British fleet.

A suit to recover $3,775 collected in taxes in July, 1928, from the Men's Faculty Club of Columbia University, has been instituted in Federal court. The club points out that it is an educational rather than social organization, and therefore cannot be taxed legally on dues and initiation fees.

NORTH WATER GAP, Pa., Sept. 18.--With a new coaching staff, a new training camp in the bracing ozone of the Pocono Mountains and a new system of attack and defensive line play, the Pennsylvania football team is headed back from the debacle of 1930, the most disastrous year in a decade of Red and Blue gridiron history.

DETROIT, Mich., Sept. 18.--The vanguard of the American Legion entered Detroit today. Although the convention does not open until Monday, thousands of delegates poured in, and the Blue and Gold uniform already was a common sight in the streets.

ALBANY, Sept. 18.--The tide of warfare over an unemployment relief bill between Governor Roosevelt and Senator Fearon and Speaker McGinnies, the Republican legislative leaders, was revealed in the exchange of correspondence today.

The first teachers' convention of Bridge Headquarters closed its week's session yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Roosevelt with some denouncement of Ely Culbertson's statement of Thursday that the new "official" system of bidding sponsored by the convention was composed 80 per cent from his own.

Since the conviction of James J. Quinlivan, former vice squad patrolman, for failure to file income tax returns, two score bootleggers, smugglers and other racketeers, fearing prosecution as tax dodgers, have flocked to the Federal offices in the city and offered to settle with the government.

LONDON, Sept. 18.--I have been kindly asked to say in these columns "what I want." The title is a misnomer. I am here in London merely as an agent for the Indian National Congress. "What I want," therefore, means what the Indian National Congress wants.

LONDON, Sept. 18.--The stocK market continued dull today, dealers reporting further liquidation from the Continent, with most of the foreign selling orders coming from Germany and Belgium. British Government funds again declined, the result of the adverse tendency in the leading foreign exchanges. The conversion 3 per cent sold at 76 and the War Loan at 99 1/8.

The United Cigar Stores Company of America leased the store at 471 Broadway, southwest corner of West Twenty-second Street, Bayonne, from Charles Grotsky for thirteen years from last July 1 at a rental of $7,200 a year.

MINEOLA, L.I., Sept. 18.--Edward V. Quinn's Lord Erin, 5-year-old chestnut gelding, took the championship rosette for hunters and jumpers at the twenty-ninth annual Mineola Horse Show today. Trolly, Bernard F. Gimbel's well-known chestnut gelding, was the reserve winner.
LONDON, Sept. 18.--Mahatma Gandhi is likely to make his long-deferred trip to the United States as soon as the round table conference on India is over.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., Sept. 18.-- Miss Charlotte Glutting, 21-year-old Baltusrol girl, who has been playing golf less than two years, became the New Jersey State champion at the Plainfield Country Club today when she won the final on the thirty-ninth hole from the champion of the last two years, Miss Martha Parker of Spring Lake.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 18.--In anticipation of oral arguments which are to be heard Monday in the petition of the nation's railroads for a 15 per cent increase in freight rates, fiftythree new briefs were filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission today.

With the grace of a fencing master and the dexterity of an acrobat, George Spitz, the 19-year-old N.Y. U. sophomore, cleared the bar at 6 feet 7 5/16 inches at Travers Island yesterday to furnish a high jumping performance that will go down in history as the second best ever made.

IF within the next week or so you encounter an insect that looks like an immensely overgrown grasshopper, at least three inches long, do not think that you are suffering from hallucinations. The insect is a praying mantis, now not an uncommon sight about New York.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 19.--Using a regular line-up for the first time since July, the Athletics today won a double header from the White Sox, 10 to 3, and 3 to 1, before a crowd of 15,000 fans. Some of the juveniles were injected into the second game line-up.

Plans Have been completed for the annual convention of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards to be held at the Sagamore, Bolton Landing, Lake George, next Thursday, Friday and Saturday. Sales of ordinary life insurance in August showed a slightly upward trend when reviewed in connection with sales during the first seven months of the year, according to the insurance sales research bureau of Hartford, Conn.

LOUIS, Sept. 29.--With aerial bombs, band music, a paper shower from tall buildings and a hearty reception from thousands who stood to watch their parade, the Cardinals, champions of the National Baseball League, today received tribute for winning their fourth league pennant in six years and equaling an 18-yearleague record of 101 victories and 53 defeats.

AMSTERDAM, Sept. 29.--Queen Wilhelmina, accompanled by Princess Juliana and the Prince Consort, inaugurated yesterday a weekly air service between Amsterdam and Batavia, the Dutch East Indies. Since September, 1930, a plane has left Holland for India every two weeks.

Palmer, Republican, of Sedalia, by a large plurality. L.L. Collins, independent wet candidate, of Springfield, ran a poor third.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 29.--Defensive baseball won't beat the world's champion Athletics in the forthcoming world's series conflict in the opinion of John Arnold Heydler, chief executive of the National League.
RICHMOND, Va., Sept. 29 (AP).-- Chief Justice Hughes urged the lawyers of the nation tonight to use ery possible means to obtain improvement in the administration of justice.

A radio message from the President and 6,000 at dinner will mark the opening of the new Waldorf-Astoria today. President Hoover has advanced his radio talk one day and will speak this evening about 6 o'clock, probably from the Cabinet room in the White House.

LONDON, Sept. 29.--Information received in London this evening to the effect that the United States was going to drop her naval building program, when shown to various members in the House of Commons lobby, was hailed by men of all parties as a most significant move in behalf of world peace.

The first sixty-nine railroads to report for August show net operating incomes of $44,513,000, against $77,198,000 in August, 1930, a drop of 42.3 per cent, and against $110,380,000 in August, 1929, a contraction of 59.6 per cent. WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--An agreement between the HollandAmerica and the Panama Pacific lines for through transportation of passengers between Pacific Coast ports and Rotterdam, with interchange at New York, was approved by the Shipping Board today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 29.--The White House today made it known that President Hoover has reached no decision as to whether a program of tax revision, looking to larger government revenues, will be submitted to the December Congress.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 29.--The Misses Natalie and Mimi Kountze, daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Herman D. Kountze, who are continuing their stay at the Muenchinger-King, were among those giving picnic luncheon parties at Bailey's Beach today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--The State Department received from Hugh R. Wilson, Minister to Switzerland, today the official text of the report and resolution adopted by the Third Committee of the Assembly of the League of Nations for a disarmament truce, after which Secretary Stimson Conferred with President Hoover on the disarmament question.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Fear of Congressional enactment of the farm export debenture plan has practically stopped the sale of American cotton in the European markets.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Government receipts for the first quarter of the fiscal year ended Sept. 28 continued the heavy decline observed prior to June 30, the total revenue for three months amounting to $577,850,700, a reduction of $243,000,000 from the same period last year.

ALBANY, Sept. 30.--Speaking on the radio tonight in behalf of the State Teachers Association to the subject "Why You Should Keep Your Child in School," Lieut. Gov. Herbert H. Lehman emphasized that one of the main objectives of President Hoover's Emergency Committee on Employment was to keep all children under 16 in school in this time of surplus labor.

HARRISON, N.Y., Sept. 30.--Paul Runyan of the Metropolis Golf Club, former New Jersey open champion, captured the Westchester open golf title today by scoring 143 for the final thirty-six holes to finish the seventy-two-hole competition at the Green Meadow Club with a total of 290.

With assurances yesterday by Corporation Counsel Hilly that New York would stop dumping refuse in the waters in and around the city by June 1, 1933, by which time its system of incinerators and reduction plants will be completed, steps were taken to end a two-year water pollution suit brought by New Jersey against New York City.
Redemption of bonds in September before their maturity dates exceeded that of the previous month and was more than three times as great as the amount returned in September, 1930.
HAVRE DE GRACE, Md., Sept. 30 (AP).--Clock Tower, owned by Morton L. Schwartz of New York, annexed the Penn A.C. Handicap, feature today at Havre de Grace.

Acting Police Captain John T. Howard, assigned to the office of Mayor Walker, tried unsuccessfully to protect from prosecution a proprietor of a speakeasy at 27 East Thirty-eighth Street, arrested in a raid in 1927, according to testimony given yesterday at a public hearing of the Hofstadter legislative committee in the County Court House.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--An opportunity will be afforded to Secretary Adams and high ranking naval officers to express themselves on the needs and present status of the navy as soon as Congress convenes, Representative Britten, chairman of the House Naval Affairs Committee, said tonight.

A sale of common stock and the immediate repurchase of class A stock in the same corporation does not constitute a "wash sale" within the meaning of the internal revenue act and the loss on the sale of the stock is deductible from income tax returns, according to the interpretation...

LONDON, Sept. 30.--An international polar exploration project has been organized for 1932, and fourteen nations have already agreed to cooperate, Dr. G.C. Simpson, director of the British Meteorological Office, announced today in an address before the British Association for the Advancement of Science.

Celebrating his twenty-fifth anniversary in wireless, David Sarnoff, president of the Radio Corporation of America, entertained at luncheon eighty-five messenger boys of the RCA Communications yesterday at the Downtown Athletic Club.
Further weakness on the Stock Exchange yesterday was the result largely of "necessitous liquidation" arising from the recent sharp scaling down of market values, in the opinion of brokers.

In its picturesque location on the grounds of the Piping Rock Club in Locust Valley, on the north shore of Long Island, the twenty-ninth annual Piping Rock horse show will start this morning, to continue through Saturday afternoon.

VIENNA, Sept. 30.--The allegation that King Zog of Albania had first taken money from Yugoslavia and then turned Albania into an Italian colony whose people starved while one-sixth of its revenues went to support his court was urged in their defense today by two of his subjects who were put on trial in the little Upper Austrian village of Ried for trying to murder him in front of the Vienna opera house last February.

A total of 160,500 of 1922 7 per cent bonds of the United States of Brazil coffee security loan has been drawn in London for redemption today at par and interest, Dillon, Read Co. announced yesterday.

The fundamental cause of Great Britain's inability to maintain the gold standard was the failure to balance its international trade, according to the National City Bank in its Oct. 1 survey of economic conditions.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Sept. 30.-- Former Mayor Edward W. Quinn of Cambridge, Democratic national committeeman for Massachusetts since 1920, died this morning, at the age of 55 years, of heart disease, after an illness of several weeks. His funeral will be held on Saturday.
If we were to offer a prize for guessing the date of the quotation which follows, the majority of our readers would probably say that the matter was written this week or last:

HAMPTON, Va., Sept. 30.--Professor Elisha Kent Kane of the University of Tennessee was held for the grand jury by Joseph E. Dixon, justice of the peace, this afternoon after a preliminary hearing on a charge of drowning his wife in Chesapeake Bay nearly three weeks ago.

Requests for listings of securities on the stock exchanges in New York in September were unusually few. It was the first month in many years in which no new bonds or stocks were admitted to the New York Stock Exchange, the total of $53,370,461 consisting only of additional stocks.
An exhibition of prints, with some pastels and drawings, by the wellknown French artist Louis Legrand opens today at the Caz-Delbo Gallery in Madison Avenue.

Mayor Walker extended the hospitality of the city yesterday to Admiral Alfredo Acton, Chief of Staff of the Royal Italian Navy, in the presence of army, navy and civic officials and a delegation of ItalianAmerican residents who had assembled at City Hall for the ceremony.

SAN FRANCISCO, Sept. 30.-- Elimination of two seeded stars and bitter battles in which other favorites were presed to the limit to stay in the running furnished the thrills today in the third round of the men's Pacific Coast singles championships.

With the avowed purpose of bringing before the public consciousness the importance of women's work and organizations, the tenth annual exposition of women's arts and industries was formerly opened last night at the Hotel Astor.

ST. PAUL, Sept.30.--An eighthinning drive over the left-field fence fence by Oscar Roettger with three men on the bases gave St. Paul the opening game of the little world's series with Rochester today, 4 to 0.

GENEVA, Sept. 30.--With the consent of the Chinese and Japanese members, the League Council this afternoon adjourned its meetings on the Sino-Japanese conflict until Oct. 14 unless in the interim an "unforeseen occurrence" renders an immediate meeting essential.

If the attitude of Broadway's bettors is an accurate gauge, the National League is due to emerge from its long world's series slump, for practically all the cash backing yesterday was going to the Cardinals and very little to the Athletics.

On Aug. 30 the Congress of Anglican and Old Catholic delegates meeting in Bonn, Germany, voted for intercommunion of their churches, subject to ratification by the Anglican authorities in England and the General Congress of the Old Catholic Churches, which closed at Vienna, Sept. 10, after having voted ratification.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--The campaign fund case of Bishop James Cannon Jr. of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, reached the Federal courts today.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--The executive committee of the National Grange went on record at a session here today in opposition to the legalization of beer, contending that such a move was opposed to the best interests ...

Movements on yesterday's financial markets were again confused. On the Stock Exchange, as early and decided recovery in railway shares reflected some positive intimations that the "four-part" trunk line arrangement had been definitely concluded and would shortly be announced.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Sept. 30.--The Central Bank of Bolivia called a conference today of the nation's business leaders to mobilize the country's credit resources against the depression.

After three years in which gold received here resulted in our holdings touching a new high mark, a sudden reversal set in about the middle of September, following the suspension of the gold standard in Great Britain and, because of record increases in earmarked metal, changed the balance for the month against the United States.
In the scheme of a Franco-German partnership for building up trade with Southern and Eastern Europe the French are cast for the role of capitalist, while the Germans supply the technical equipment.

Deluged by mail and perturbed by the incessant whistling of students who paraded up and down the corridor adjoining his office, Dr. Charles Gray Shaw, Professor of Philosophy at New York University, who asserted Monday that "if men whistle they usually are morons," turned a tired face to an interviewer yesterday and declared that he wished to modify his statement.

Detectives of the Lost Property Bureau at Police Headquarters arrested three men yesterday afternoon in a pawnshop on Sixth Avenue near Forty-fourth Street and charged them with the theft, last month, of jewelry valued at $10,000 from the home of Frederick Levinthal at 1,823 Avenue R. Brooklyn.

Returns to date indicate that net operating incomes of all Class I railroads in August were about $56,500,000, against $95,603,000 in August, 1930, a drop of 40 per cent, and against $141,758,000 in August, 1929, a decrease of 60 per cent. Their net operating incomes in July were $56,903,000.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Sept. 30.-- Governor Roosevelt of New York came back to his "other home" tonight and was hailed by the leading Democrats of Georgia as a certain Presidential nominee on the first ballot and an equally certain victor for the Presidency in 1932.

SHANGHAI, Sept. 30.--Colonel and Mrs. Charles A. Lindbergh, accompanied by Dr. Borcic, League of Nations health official, landed their plane on the Yangtse River at Hankow at 3 o'clock this afternoon, coming down beside the British aircraft carrier Hermes.
There was no change in the interest rate for call loans on the New York Stock Exchange in September, the 1 per cent charge which had been in effect since May 13 ruling throughout the month.

With testimony that Otto H. Kahn, banker and patron of music, failed to "replenish" a $150,000 fund established for Mme. Lydia Lindgren. Swedish singer, in 1926 Mme. Lindgren rested her $500,000 breach of contract action against him yesterday in Queens Supreme Court.
Three members appointed by Governor Roosevelt to constitute the State Emergency Relief Administration will be sworn in at Albany today by Acting Governor Herbert H. Lehman.

Preliminary plans for city action to bring about a general revision of the electric rates of the four companies of the Edison system were discussed yesterday at a City Hall conference in which Mayor Walker, Corporation Counsel Hilly and representatives of real estate groups participated.
TOKYO, Sept. 30.--A high naval officer indicated in an interview today that Japan's difficulties regarding proposals for a naval holiday were not strategical but industrial.

Although current buying still reflects the cautious attitude of consuming interests, the steel business shows some improvement in certain districts and the rate of operations in the industry has been advanced slightly, according to the midweek trade reviews.

Ten of the outstanding advocates of United States participation in the World Court met yesterday in an uptown club to plan a nation-wide drive for ratification by the Senate of the pending World Court proposal.

With the report yesterday of only seventeen new cases of infantile paralysis for the twenty-four-hour period ended in the morning, Health Commissioner Wynne was "hopeful" that the outbreak would be over by the end of this week. The figure yesterday was the lowest since July 10.

MONTREAL, Que., Sept. 30 (Canadian Press).--In view of discussions of bonuses to shareholders of certain chartered banks this year, Beaudry Leman, president of the Canadian Bankers' Association, today issued the following statement:

Chief City Magistrate James E. McDonald ordered yesterday the transfer of eight-seven attaches in the lower courts, composed entirely of assistant court clerks and attendants, to new posts, effective today.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30. --A Farm, even slightly torrid, Indian Summer day greeted the inpouring host of baseball enthusiasts that assembled on the west bank of the Mississippi today in elaborate and noisy preparation for the playing of the first game of the 1931 world's series, which opens at Sportsman's Park tomorrow.
Bishop William T. Manning said last evening that he did not wish to make any comment "at this time" on the new canon on divorce adopted by the general convention in Denver.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Revised rates paid to contracting operators for transporting air mail, which will reduce the Postoffice Department's expenses by at least $700,000 a year, will go into effect tomorrow as the result of an order issued by Postmaster General Brown.

A man with four names and a national police record of twelve arrests led two policemen and 500 clerks and Wall Street runners over a fast six-minute course in the heart of the financial district yesterday afternoon.
A plea of not guilty to forgery and grand larceny indictments was entered before Judge Allen in General Sessions yesterday by Palmer Canfield, former prohibition administrator ...

For the third successive session prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday made new bottoms for the year. October sold at 5.81 cents a pound, the lowest quotation since August, 1899, while weakness in securities and increased selling by producers carried the December down to 6.02 cents.

The Whitestone branch of the Long Island Railroad, serving five communities in Queens, will continue in to operate at least until a Federal Statutory Court decides on the Transit Commission's application for an interlocutory injunction against the Interstate Commerce Commission's order authorizing abandonment of the line on or after Oct. 15.

Promoters of the "No Deal Judiciary party" now being organized in the Second Judicial District were awaiting yesterday the action of the Brooklyn Bar Association and similar bodies in other parts of the district before finally determining upon a course.

BERLIN, Sept. 30.--The government's plans for wage reductions have already brought strikes in Ruhr coal mines, and two prominent members of the Socialist party who oppose the pay cuts have announced they will revive the old Independent Socialist party, out of which the Communist party developed.
PARIS, Sept. 30.--Premier Laval, it was decided this evening, will leave Paris for his visit to Washington on the Ile de France on Oct. 16.

GENEVA, N.Y., Sept. 30 (AP).--Dr. Lucius Lincoln Van Slyke, for thirtyeight years a chemist and research worker at the New York State Agricultural Experiment Station here, died at his home today after an ill.

LONDON, Sept. 30.--The Stock Exchange generally was dull today. Selling was not in large volume, but there was no buying power, particularly in the industrials, where business was considerably restricted by the ban on free dealings.
New York's past and present met yesterday afternoon to welcome back one of the city's best-known institutions, the Waldorf.

The controversy centring about the terms of a new wage contract for longshoremen on the transatlantic piers was settled yesterday by committees representing the ship lines and the International Longshoremen's Union, thus eliminating the possibility of a strike which was to have started this morning.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--A note explaining Sweden's temporary suspension of the gold standard and stating that Sweden's finances were in a strong position was delivered to Secretary Stimson today by W. Bostrom, the Swedish Minister.
