Arrangements have been made for the sale of a membership in the New York Stock Exchange at $156,000, a decline of $4,000 from the preceding sale and the lowest price for a membership since November, 1926, when a seat was transferred for $152,000, it was announced yesterday.
WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Vs., Sept. 30.--Women's singles and doubles, men's doubles and mixed doubles were played today in the third annual Greenbrier Autumn tennis tournament.

PRINCETON, N.J., Sept. 30.-- Practicing until stopped by darkness today, the Princeton varsity football squad was given its last hard workout before the Amherst game Saturday. In a drill which lasted over two hours, the all-around playing of Purnell and the ball-carrying of Van Dyke were outstanding.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the heaviest of any month since last June. Sales in September totaled 51,139,897 shares, compared with 24,890,277 shares in August and 53,545,145 shares in the corresponding month a year ago.

WESTPORT, Conn., Sept. 30.--The body of Kenneth Raisbeck, 32 years old, a playwright, was found in the Christ Church Cemetery here today under conditions which led to a difference of opinion among local authorities as to whether he was murdered or, as W.H. McMahon, medical examiner of Norwalk, decided after an autopsy, died of acute meningitis.

Of the thousands who explored the magnificences of the new Hotel Waldorf-Astoria last night a handful recalled the opening of its predecessor, the original Waldorf and the wonder of its day, more than thirty-eight years ago.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30--"The main reason I think we will win the world's series," said Jimmie Wilson, catcher and mainspring of the Cardinals' defensive department today, "is the way our boys are approaching the battle as compared to their demeanor and utterances this time last year.

A plan he believed would "restore prosperity" within sixty days from the time it was begun by the government was disclosed yesterday by Edwin Ross Thomas, 80-year-old retired automobile man and fruitgrower of Miami Beach, Fla.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., Sept. 30.-- Major Gen. Edwin St. John Greble, U.S.A., retired, died here today at the age of 72, in the home of his son, Edwin St. John Greble Jr., on Prospect Avenue, after a long illness. He was in the service from 1881 to 1918.
SHANGHAI, Sept. 30.--The general movement favoring war against Japan seems to be spreading rapidly, apparently with the encouragement of the Nanking Government.

While plus signs were not numerous yesterday in bonds of domestic corporations, some high-grade foreign loans made important recoveries. United States Government bonds were again generally lower in heavy trading.
BUDAPEST, Sept. 30.--This city, following Vienna's example, now plans to ship southward swallows which have been unable to fly on account of the early onset of Winter.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 30.--Although the Democratic leaders in the Legislature have agreed tentatively to the program for unemployment relief outlined yesterday at a nonpartisan conference called by Governor Larson, Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City took exception today to the provision that municipalities and local districts receiving State aid must supply more than an equal amount of money.

Charles M. Rosenthal, 23 years old, member of a curb brokerage concern who lives at Lawrence, L.I., testified as the first State witness yesterday in the General Sessions trial of four men and a young mulatto woman on an indictment charging they kidnapped him for the $50,000 ransom his mother paid last Aug 18, and held him captive in a West Harlem apartment for seventeen days.
LONDON, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press).--The British Association for the Advancement of Science concluded its centenary meeting today.
Five young women and 152 young men, who are applicants for admission to the bar, were directed yesterday by the committee on character and fitness of the Appellate Division, ...

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Warning was given today to the Interstate Commerce Commission by representatives of financial interests that numerous railway wage controversies are probable if the railroads' application for a freight-rate increase is denied.

Foreign central banks yesterday converted an additional $19,300,000 of their dollar balances into gold and placed it under earmark at the Federal Reserve Bank, bringing the total of gold set aside for foreign account since the fall of the pound sterling from the gold standard on Sept. 21 to $270,386,000.

The problems of the mortgage market have been added to by wage cutting and the foreign situation, with lenders cautious and steadily exerting pressure on an already severely restricted money market, according to Brooks, Harvey Co., Inc., mortgage investment brokers.
Renewed selling of all classes of securities brought new low record prices for many stocks and bonds on the New York Curb Exchange yesterday. A few of the foreign bonds were stronger.
WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Sept. 30. --A trio of golfers from the Gedney Farm Golf Club captured all three prizes in the Westchester one-day tournament held today at the Westchester Hills Golt Club.

The directors of the Baltimore Ohio Railroad declared yesterday a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock. In the two preceding quarters dividends of $1.25 a share were paid, prior to which the stock was on a $7 annual basis.

The railroad presidents have reached tentative agreements on details which until now have prevented the realignment of the Eastern lines into four trunk systems and, unless last-minute obstacles arise, will soon embody their views in a petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

BERLIN, Sept. 30.--The following dispatch has been received from the German Greenland expedition, signed by Professor Kurt Wegener, brother of the party's former leader, Professor Alfred Wegener, who perished on the ice cap:

A bequest of about $230,000 to a public foundation created in Germany by her late husband was provided by Mrs. Katherine Quick Nissen, who died in Brooklyn, Dec. 28, 1930, it was disclosed yesterday in a transfer tax report filed in Surrogate's Court in Brooklyn.

Homesickness at last has claimed Manuel and Diosaner, natives of Africa who were brought here in July by Martin Johnson to care for the three gorillas and the two chimpanzees the explorer captured in the Belgian Congo.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--A new race, brown skinned, formed of the fusion of blacks, whites and yellow browns, a group new in biological make-up, has been developed, 12,000,000 strong, in the United States, according to Edwin R. Embree, president of the Julius Rosenwald Fund.
ROCK ISLAND, Ill., Sept. 30.-- Police were called to handle crowds which started runs today on all of the city's financial institutions.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.--Red Faber and his White Sox mates reached out of the cellar of the American League today to hand the Cubs a 9-to-0 defeat in the opening battle of the Chicago city championship series at Wrigley Field before a crowd of 15,000.
DENVER, Sept. 30.--The Episcopal Church demanded today that the United States join the League of Nations.

DANBURY, Conn., Sept. 30.--News of the wave of prosperity caused by the craze for Eugenie hats has already traveled so fast that this town, which makes at least 85 per cent of the nation's headgear, has become a mecca for the jobless.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Sept. 30.-- Continuing to play the brand of golf he showed yesterday, although not scoring quite as low, T. Henry Clarkson of Old Belleclaire won the metropolitan seniors' golf championship at the Garden City Golf Club today with something to spare in the way of strokes.

Harry Braun, 22-year-old violinist, whose $25,000 Guarnerius violin was crushed Tuesday evening beneath the wheels of a truck at Fifth Avenue and Forty-third Street, will not sue the truck driver for damages, he said yesterday after learning that the driver was a poor man.
As a murder play, "Payment Deferred," which was acted at the Lyceum last evening, has a novel twist that makes for satisfactory shuddering.

LONDON, Sept. 30.--Mounted and foot police clashed today with unemployed demonstrators and Communists on a march to the Bow Street Court, where charges were heard against the men and women arrested during last night's disturbances outside the House of Commons.

NEWPORT, R.I., Sept. 30.--Repairs are being made to the Cadwalader house, near the end of Bellevue Avenue, which has caused a rumor that this estate, which has been unoccupied this Summer, soon will change ownership.
The New York Cocoa Exchange will celebrate today its sixth anniversary. As a coincidence, the commodity that caused the organization of the Exchange is at the lowest price in history.

CHICAGO, Sept. 30.-- The September wheat delivery expired today in a tame fashion with a net loss of 1 1/8 cents, and sold at the lowest price since trading in futures started on the Chicago Board of Trade.

MADRID, Sept. 30--Cardinal Pedro Segura y Saenz, Archbishop of Toledo and Primate of Spain, has resigned his primacy. His resignation was accepted by the Vatican and handed to President Alcala Zamora formally by the Papal Nuncio today.

TRENTON, N.J., Sept. 30.--While speculation about the beer legalization compact effected at the Republican Congressional delegation's conference was stimulated by the failure of David Baird Jr., Republican Gubernatorial candidate, its designated spokesman, to reveal its results.

If there were any doubts about Pardee's qualifications for the Junior Champion, the mile stake on Saturday, they were dissipated completely yesterday when the Belair Stud colorbearer won the Oakdale claiming stakes, feature at Aqueduct, and scored his third successive victory.
Apartment houses in resales and foreclosure proceedings and several taxpayer structures were among the New Jersey deals reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Democratic satisfaction over the election of the party's candidate for Congress in the Seventh Missouri District was expressed today by Jouett Shouse, chairman of the Executive Committee of the Democratic National Committee.
LONDON, Sept. 30.--Premier MacDonald announced in the House of Commons today that Parliament would adjourn next Wednesday.

The maintenance of dividend payments by domestic corporations was urged yesterday by Simon Guggenheim president of the American Smelting and Refining Company, who returned from Europe on Tuesday. Mr. Guggenheim said that, in consideration of the smaller stockholders, dividends should be maintained as long as it was possible to do so without borrowing money.
New securities offered in September about equaled the amount in August, but were only about onequarter of the total of September, 1930.

Romance, woven in the traditions of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration--better known as The Little Church Around the Corner--retains today its strong hold on that edifice, according to the church history, "Through the LichGate," to be published today by William Farquhar Payson.

CALSHOT, England, Sept. 30.-- Flight Lieutenant G.H. ATLANTA, Sept. 30 (AP).--Increased retail trade, greater consumption of cotton and improvement in production of coal in Alabama and Tennessee were shown today in the monthly business review by the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta.

That Tammany Hall is determined to gain control of the Assembly at the legislative elections this year with a view to cutting short the life of the Hofstadter committee, now investigating the conduct of the New York City Government under a Tammany administration, is being used by the Republicans in this city as their chief argument to draw a large registration of party voters during the week beginning next Monday.

TORONTO, Sept. 30.--Miss Enid Wilson, British champion, played by far the best game she has displayed since her arrival from abroad a few weeks ago in eliminating Miss Mary K. Browne of Cleveland today by 5 and 3 in the second round of the women's Canadian golf championship.

The reorganization committee of the Tri-Utilities Corporation has completed its plan, copies of which will be distributed to security holders on or about next Monday, Richard C. Hunt, chairman, announced yesterday.

COLLINSVILLE, Ill., Sept. 30 (AP). --Dark Sea, the improved 4-year-old son of Traumer-Dinahmeur, racing under the silks of Herbert M. Woolf, Kansas City sportsman, galloped to victory in the $10,000 added Fairmount Handicap today before a cheering throng of 6,000.
PARIS, Sept. 30.--Sixteen American makes of cars will be represented in the twenty-fifth annual Paris automobile salon, which opens tomorrow at the Grand Palais with eight countries participating.

President HIBBEN of Princeton has suggested that the spirit of the universities, far from being one of depression, should be rather that of "elation" that the opportunity has come to show an understanding sense of an obligation which one would wish not to escape.

Deaths may further change the balance of the two major parties in the Senate and the House. But the result of the special election in the Seventh Missouri District has proved --what almost every one believed-- that the trend is with the Democrats.

WILKES-BARRE, Pa., Sept. 30.-- The wage-cutting orders of several corporations, including the United States Steel Corporation, were denounced at the final session of the Catholic Charities Conference today by Dr. Francis H. Haas, director of the National Catholic School of Social Service at Washington.

THE statisticians and technicians had it figured out many years ago that the clawing Cubs of Husk Chance would annihilate the White Sox Hitless Wonders in their world's series debate. The White Sox took four out of six.

OTTAWA, Sept. 30 (Canadian Press).--The government today advanced another stage in its efforts to strike a balance between Canadian and British manufacturers when it decreed by order-in-council that the dumping duty would be applied on importations from Great Britain and thus eliminated the discount on British currency in this country.
Both Governor ROOSEVELT and the State are to be congratulated on his choice of members of the Temporary Relief Administration.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Plans of the Southern Pacific Company to acquire control of the St.Louis Southwestern Railway System by stock purchase were supported by the latter company in a brief filed today with the Interstate Commerce Commission taking exception to an adverse report on the project by T.F. Sullivan, examiner.

Usually one of the months in which the largest disbursements of the year are made, September was marked by numerous omissions and reductions of dividends.
The detention of two men for questioning in connection with the murder of Benjamin P. Collings was announced last night in dispatches from Daytona Beach, Fla.

WASHINGTON, Sept. 30.--Declines of 12.4 per cent in employment and 20.8 per cent in payroll totals of manufacturing industries in August below those for the same month last year were shown in an analysis issued today by the Department of Labor.
TOKYO, Sept. 30.--Japanese Charge d'Affaires Shigemitsu at Nanking reports serious interference with news and cable messages by the Chinese telegraph office at Shanghai.

ST. LOUIS, Sept. 30 (AP).--The Cincinnati Nationals tonight drafted Clyde Manion, promising catcher, from the Milwaukee club of the American Association at the opening of the draft meeting, presided over by Commissioner Kenesaw M. Landis.
Dawn BAIRD, Republican candidate for Governor of New Jersey, should be allowed to speak for himself on the subject of beer in the campaign.

Gerard, former Ambassador to Germany and crusader against bear oparators in the stock market, told the Advertising Club at a luncheon in his honor yesterday.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Sept. 30-- When General John Burgoyne faced defeat at Saratoga in 1777, George Bernard Shaw in his American Revolutionary play has made him say, "some gentleman in London" forgot to dispatch orders to General Howe at New York to support him.

Concerted action by all States concerned for the solution of the problem of over-production of cotton was urged yesterday by Bernard M. Baruch, who was chairman of the War Industries Board during the war.

LONDON, Sept. 30.--Sir William Orpen, one of England's outstanding artists, died in a hospital here yesterday. He had been seriously ill for some time. He would have been 53 years old in another month.

PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 30.--One of the biggest upsets in women's golf in years was registered today when Mrs. Glenna Collett Vare, recently dethroned as national champion by Miss Helen Hicks, met defeat in the first round of the Berthellyn Cup tournament at the Huntingdon Valley course.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Sept. 30.-- During the impending celebration of Wesleyan University's centennial one of the attractions arranged for the entertainment of the educators and statesmen who will congregate here to join in the chorus of felicitations is a football game with Columbia on Oct. 10.

Plans for a vehicular tunnel under the East River opposite Thirtyeighth Street, with an extension under Murray Hill to the west side of Manhattan, have been given much expert study since they were first broached by the Fifth Avenue Association.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Sept. 30.-- Need for Federal relief in more than one part of the United States this Winter to prevent cold and hungry workmen from being "driven to desperation" is predicted in the annual report of the officers of the metal trades department of the American Federation of Labor.

Were twelve additional Supreme Court Justices needed in the Second Judicial District, comprising Kings, Queens, Richmond, Nassau and Suffolk? According to Mr. CHARLES C. BURLINGHAM, three or four would have been enough.

A suit for a permanent injunction to restrain Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, Chauffeurs, Stablemen and Helpers of America from interference with drivers of four trucking companies having headquarters in Connecticut has been started in the United States District Court here.

The peak of New York's annual moving season was passed yesterday with little evidence of congestion, despite an unexpectedly large number of last-minute orders which brought the total number of changes close to last year's figures.

A fine acid spray, descending from the smoke screen which an airplane threw around the naval airship Los Angeles above Manhattan at 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon, caused widespread complaints of smarting faces and ruined clothing among watchers in the streets below.

Kingsland Macy and County Judge George H. Furman were mentioned, adjourned today without finding grounds for indictment. The charges were made by State Senator John J. Dunnigan, Democratic leader of the Senate.

PARIS, Sept. 30.--The formation of a police organization to be known as the International World Police, comprising representatives of all governments, was provided in a joint resolution adopted at the closing sessions today of the International Police Conference and the International Criminal Police Commission.

A check-up on former public school teachers receiving disability-retirement pensions from the city was ordered yesterday by the Teachers Retirement Board with the discovery that many of the disability pensioners have been married since they left active service and that others have recovered sufficiently to be restored to duty.

Colonel Ernest McCullough, engineer, architect, soldier, editor and author, died yesterday at his home, 41-12 Forty-eighth Street, Long Island City, Queens, after an illness of three days. He was 64 years old. He had specialized for the last twenty years in building design and construction and previously had been engaged in general engineering.

An appeal to the business interests of the city to support generously the work of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, which plans to raise $12,000,000, was made yesterday by Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the committee in an address before the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York.

The Macy Galleries opened yesterday their second exhibition of the season devoted to the work of contemporary American artists. A separate room has now been placed at the disposal of the exhibiting artists, which greatly adds to the effectiveness of the display.

CHICAGO, Oct. 1.--The first American Bible, simplified and modernized in phraseology, will soon be published by the University of Chicago Press. A further decline in brokers' loans, amounting to $35,000,000 for the week ended Wednesday, was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank, compared with $64,000,000 a week ago and with $54,000,000 two weeks ago.

LONDON, Oct. 1.--Sir Thomas Lipton, 81, is seriously ill at his London home, suffering from the effects of a severe chill. His condition today was causing grave anxiety to the four physicians attending him, but they hoped that the veteran yachtsman's rugged constitution would bull him through.

PARIS, Oct. 1.--Further drastic steps to protect the home market from foreign competition, especially from countries whose currencies may soon be depreciated, were taken today by the French Government.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1.--Weather clear, track fast. The early comers at Sportsman's Park were trying to guess Connie Mack's starting pitcher. This included the Philadelphia players, who weren't half as sure as some of the tourists from Des Moines. Mickey Cochrane, for instance, thought that Moose Earnshaw would be heaving his fast ones over for the Athletics. Other players had a suspicion that Walberg might be elected. Grove led on most ballots, however.

PARIS, Oct. 1.--Addresses urging Franco-American cooperation by President Paul Doumer and Ambassador Walter E. Edge were broadcast to the United States today on the occasion of the dedication of Pershing Hall, the American Legion's magnificent new home in France, built by subscriptions from all parts of the United States.
NEWPORT, R.I. Oct. 1.--Mrs. George Fritz Chandler entertained with a tea at Maplehurst today.

The directors of the Columbia Gas and Electric Company declared a dividend of 37 cents a share yesterday on the no par common stock of the company, compared with 50 cents quarterly previously paid, and regular quarterly dividends on the preferred stocks.

Foreign central banks yesterday earmarked an additional $24,200,000 of gold and $7,465,800 of the metal was withdrawn from the Federal Reserve Bank for shipment abroad, bringing the day's net loss to the gold stocks of the country up to $31,665,800.

A further drop in infantile paralysis was recorded by the Health Department yesterday in the report of only fifteen new cases of the disease for the twenty-four-hour period ended in the morning. The downward trend served to substantiate the pre diction that the outbreak virtually would be over by the end of the week.

ST. LOUIS, Oct. 1--Connie Mac became ultra-modern today in deaing with post-game interviewer. The venerable director of the Phildelphia, Athletics closed the clu house doors to folks who wanted hear at first-hand his reactions his team's one-sided triumph.

A tentative assessment of $19,296,985,571 is placed against taxable real estate in New York City on the tentative assessment rolls for 1932 made public yesterday by James J. Sexton, president of the Department of Taxes and Assessments. The tentative increase is $1,117,166,654.

PHILADELPHIA, Oct.1--Two women golfers from the metropolitan district reached the semi-final round of the Berthellyn Cup tournament today by turning in impressive second-round victories over the Huntingdon Valley links.

Magistrate Louis B. Brodsky revealed last night that he has been conducting an experiment in Night Court on West Fifty-fourth Street which may, if approved, lead to the establishment of free public counsel in the city's magistrates' courts.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., Oct. 1.--Twice breaking par figures in two dazzling rounds of 71 for a total of 142. Gene Sarazen of Lakeville, national open champion of 1922, far outdistanced a field of fifty-seven to win the medal in the Metropolitan P.G.A. championship tournament at the Rockville Country Club today.

GREENWICH, Conn., Oct. 1.--Miss Catherine Singer of the Westchester Country Club won the Elizabeth Wheeler Trophy for the best low gross score for 54 holes in the annual women's golf championship of Westchester and Fairfield Counties, which a ded at the Greenwich Country Club today. Her score was 260 for the three days.

Suspension of the New York Stock Exchange firm of Curtis Sanger, a moderate-sized financial house engaged in the brokerage and investment banking business, was announced yesterday after it had given notice of its inability to meet its engagements.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., Oct. 1.--Competition in the men's singles, women's singles and mixed doubles reached the final round in the third annual Greenbrier Autumn tennis tournament today.

Mrs. Lillian C. Collings, widow of Benjamin P. Ritchie and his son William, who are held in Daytona Beach, Fla., for investigation in the Collings mystery.
Lefty Grove, vulnerable but still victorious, shifted the Broadway betting odds by his initial triumph over the Cardinals and the youthful Paul Derringer yesterday.
